descriptions.content:
Description

Rituals for purifying the body, psychic obstructions, sites, physical objects, and so forth.

Note that the words sbyang chog and khrus chog also have funerary connotations (see "Death rituals"), but many of these rituals are for the living. Also, there is a need to distinguish between rituals of bathing buddhas/deities (khrus gsol, which are forms of offerings) and rituals meant to purify (khrus chog), which belong here.

Related Terms

sbyangs chog, khrus chog, byab khrus

Example Texts

  • kun rig la brten pa’i gson por sbyang chog (W6138)
  • gshin po'i sbyang chog lhan thabs (W7837)
  • sbyang chog gi lag len dang khungs gsal bar bkod pa rgyud don gsal ba’i rgyan (W1061)
  • tshe ldan la sbyangs chod byed tshul (W17991)
  • See also TBRC topic T175 (sbyang chog)

Secondary Sources

Karmay, Samten. "The Local Deities and the Juniper Tree: A Rite for Purification." In The Arrow and the Spindle: Studies in History, Myth, Rituals and Beliefs in Tibet, 380-412. Kathmandu: Mandala Book Point, 1998.

Norbu, Namkhai. "The Bön of Exorcisms: The Rites for Purification." In Drung, Deu and Bön: Narrations, Symbolic Languages and the Bön Tradition in Ancient Tibet, 103-125. Dharamsala: Library of Tibetan Works and Archives, 1995.
